subject: First Layer Issues
object: Nozzle too close to the bed

subject: First Layer Issues
object: Nozzle too far away from the print bed

subject: First Layer Issues
object: Print Not Sticking

subject: Nozzle too close to the bed
object: Printed line is thinner than desired.

subject: Nozzle too close to the bed
object: Excess filament is squished upwards at the edges of the current printing line creating a rough surface and wavy patterns.

subject: Nozzle too close to the bed
object: Filament is getting torn off the bed when the next neighbouring line is printed.

subject: Nozzle too close to the bed
object: Finished prints are hard to remove from the print bed.

subject: Nozzle too close to the bed
object: Adjust nozzle to bed distance either by tightening the 3 or 4 levelling screws of your printer and using thicker paper stock for manual bed levelling or by adjusting your z-offset value when using a bed levelling sensor. Make sure you’re not pressing down on your bed when levelling it.

subject: Nozzle too far away from the print bed
object: When looking at the bottom of your printed object, you can clearly make out individual lines with a noticeable gap between each line.

subject: Nozzle too far away from the print bed
object: During printing the first layer, the individual lines are not touching each other.

subject: Nozzle too far away from the print bed
object: There’s small gaps where the lines of the infill are not touching the outlines of the wall.

subject: Nozzle too far away from the print bed
object: The shape of the extruding line is very round. With the proper distance, extruded line is slightly squished, pancake shaped.

subject: Nozzle too far away from the print bed
object: Individual printed lines are barely sticking to the build plate.

subject: Nozzle too far away from the print bed
object: Parts are warping off the build plate or become loose during the prints.

subject: Nozzle too far away from the print bed
object: Adjust nozzle to bed distance either by loosening the 3 or 4 levelling screws of your printer and using thinner paper stock (receipt paper is good) for manual bed levelling or by adjusting your z-offset value when using a bed levelling sensor. Make sure you’re not pressing the bed upwards while levelling manually.

subject: Print Not Sticking
object: Your print is lifting off the bed, such as warping, or returning to your printer with a birds nest.

subject: Print Not Sticking To The Bed
object: Platform not level

subject: Print Not Sticking To The Bed
object: Platform is warped

subject: Print Not Sticking To The Bed
object: Your bed is not clean

subject: Print Not Sticking To The Bed
object: Nozzle too close to the bed

subject: Print Not Sticking To The Bed
object: Nozzle too far away from the print bed

subject: Print Not Sticking To The Bed
object: Print First layer too fast

subject: Print Not Sticking To The Bed
object: Wrong extrusion settings

subject: Print Not Sticking To The Bed
object: Print temperature for first layer

subject: Print Not Sticking To The Bed
object: Bed temperature for first layer

subject: Print Not Sticking To The Bed
object: Part cooling fan settings

subject: Platform not level
object: Nozzle too close to the bed

subject: Platform not level
object: Nozzle too far away from the print bed

subject: Nozzle too close to the bed
object: The left side of your nozzle is too close and the right side it is fine or even too high up, your bed is most likely at an angle – not level with the nozzle. Same goes for front and back and of course this can happen in both axis at the same time.

subject: Nozzle too far away from the print bed
object: The left side of your nozzle is too close and the right side it is fine or even too high up, your bed is most likely at an angle – not level with the nozzle. Same goes for front and back and of course this can happen in both axis at the same time.

subject: Platform not level
object:
adjusting 3 or 4 screws under the print bed: In order to do so:

(1) Heat up your bed and nozzle to proper printing temperature, retract filament a bit and make sure the nozzle is clean (and no filament is oozing out during the levelling process).
(2) Move the heated nozzle to the first corner of the bed.
(3) Slide a piece of paper between the bed and the nozzle. Loosen or tighten the bed level for that corner screw until you notice a bit of drag when sliding the paper under it.
(4) Continue to the next corner, position your nozzle over it, adjust the screw so you get the same amount of drag.
(5) Do so for at least all for corners, then check the middle of the bed.

subject: Platform is warped
object: Printed line is thinner than desired.

subject: Platform is warped
object: Excess filament is squished upwards at the edges of the current printing line creating a rough surface and wavy patterns.

subject: Platform is warped
object: Filament is getting torn off the bed when the next neighbouring line is printed.

subject: Platform is warped
object: Finished prints are hard to remove from the print bed.

subject: Platform is warped
object: When looking at the bottom of your printed object, you can clearly make out individual lines with a noticeable gap between each line.

subject: Platform is warped
object: During printing the first layer, the individual lines are not touching each other.

subject: Platform is warped
object: There’s small gaps where the lines of the infill are not touching the outlines of the wall.

subject: Platform is warped
object: The shape of the extruding line is very round. With the proper distance, extruded line is slightly squished, pancake shaped.

subject: Platform is warped
object: Individual printed lines are barely sticking to the build plate.

subject: Platform is warped
object: Parts are warping off the build plate or become loose during the prints.

subject: Platform is warped
object: use a steel ruler or a straight edge, put it onto your bed and look at the gap between the edge and the bed.

subject: Platform is warped
object: if you levelled the bed for all 4 corners, but the midpoint or some random points on the bed are off, then your bed is warped (or the axis bent)

subject: Platform is warped
object: print a very thick first layer(but do not exceed maximum layer height = 75% nozzle size. i.e. 0.3mm for a 0.4mm nozzle)

subject: Platform is warped
object: try printing with a raft

subject: Platform is warped
object: pick a smaller area in the center of the build plate and try to level it as best as possible there

subject: Your bed is not clean
object: You see debris from a previous print, dust, gunk, spots, etc

subject: Your bed is not clean
object: You see lumps, build-up or an uneven coat of your favourite bed adhesive.

subject: Your bed is not clean
object: You see some dents in the otherwise smooth bottom surface of a finished print.

subject: Your bed is not clean
object: Degrease your bed surface regularly according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Use either isopropyl alcohol/isopropanol in a high concentration or pure acetone. Stay away from window cleaners, dish washing liquids and soaps, especially those who are supposed to be good for your skin, as most of them will leave a residue behind that will negatively affect bed adhesion.

subject: Print First layer too fast
object: The extruder can’t keep up with pushing filament through at this speed and you see [Under Extrusion]

subject: Print First layer too fast
object: Every proper slicer out there has the option to specify a different print speed for your first layer. In Cura, it is called “Initial Layer speed”. In Simplify3D it is called “First Layer Speed”. We're pretty sure your slicer has this setting as well, under some variation of those names. Usually a speed of 30mm/s or less is good for the first layer, you can increase the speed later on but experimenting is key.

subject: Wrong extrusion settings
object: Under extrusion

subject: Wrong extrusion settings
object: Over extrusion

subject: Wrong extrusion settings
object: Infill leaving gaps

subject: Wrong extrusion settings
object: walls turn out too thin

subject: Wrong extrusion settings
object: layers not thick enough (not squished)

subject: Wrong extrusion settings
object: Calibrate the extruder steps required to extrude the requested amount of filament.

subject: Wrong extrusion settings
object: Check your extrusion multiplier in your slicer software to ensure proper amount of filament is extruded.

subject: Wrong extrusion settings
object: Check that you selected the proper filament size (1.75mm/2.85mm/3.00mm) in your slicer.

subject: Wrong extrusion settings
object: Ensure filament can be transported properly (i.e. filament unspools freely from the spool, no excess friction in the filament path).

subject: Wrong extrusion settings
object: Ensure nozzle isn’t blocked or partially blocked. This is a very common cause of under-extrusion or uneven extrusion. See [Clogged Nozzle].

subject: Print temperature for first layer
object: prints not sticking / warping

subject: Print temperature for first layer
object: rough corners

subject: Print temperature for first layer
object: curling or sloppy overhangs

subject: Print temperature for first layer
object: Almost all slicers out there will allow you to set a different print temperature for your first/initial layer. Use this feature to adjust bed adhesion without it affecting the rest of your print.

subject: Bed temperature for first layer
object: prints not sticking / warping

subject: Bed temperature for first layer
object: Elephant foot

subject: Bed temperature for first layer
object: curling close to the bed

subject: Bed temperature for first layer
object: Look up the glass transition temperature of the material you’re printing. Ensure your bed temperature is at least around 10°C below the glass transition temperature. If your bed is far below the glass transition temperature and you’re having trouble with your print not sticking, increase your bed temperature in 5°C increments until the issue is resolved (staying below the GT temp)

subject: Part cooling fan settings
object: your part cooling fan is spinning while printing the first layer you need to look at your fan settings.

subject: Part cooling fan settings
object: Disable the part cooling fan for the first layer.
